anchor.surface_text: Reliance is placed upon two recent decisions of this Court which, following the earlier decision reported in Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala 1 have laid down that Government should give reasons when it performs quasi-judicial functions such as hearin- appeals and revisions. The two cases are Madhya Pradesh Industries Ltd. v. Union of India and Ors. 2 and Aluminium Corporation of India Ltd. v. Union of India and Ors 3 In Harinagar Sugar Mills 1 the order was reversed on the ground that reasons for the decision should have appeared.

issues.text: Whether the procedure under Rule 54 of the Mineral Concession Rules 1960 was correctly followed by the Central Government?

anchor.surface_text: The firm thereupon filed an application for revision before the Central Government under Rule 54 of the Mineral Concession Rules 1960. ... The Central Government asked for the comments of the State Government on the application and invited the firm to make its own comments upon the reply of the State Government.

arguments.claim: There was a breach of Clause 3 of Part VII of the lease by failing to continue work without voluntary intermission in a skilful and workman-like manner.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  3  of Part VII of the lease is one of the companyenants by the lessee and under it the lessee undertook to companytinue work, without voluntary intermission, in a skilful and workman-like-manner. Under cls.  i  to  x  of Rule 41 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949 and under Rule 27 5  of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1960 power is companyferred on the State Government to require the lessee by numberice to remove a breach within 60 days of the receipt of numberice and in default to determine the lease and forfeit the whole or part of the security in deposit.

arguments.claim: State Government had power under Rule 41 MCR 1949 and Rule 27(5) MCR 1960 to issue notice to remedy breach within 60 days or terminate the lease.

anchor.surface_text: Under cls.  i  to  x  of Rule 41 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949 and under Rule 27 5  of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1960 power is companyferred on the State Government to require the lessee by numberice to remove a breach within 60 days of the receipt of numberice and in default to determine the lease and forfeit the whole or part of the security in deposit. Under Rule 27 1  f  the lessee is also required to companyduct operations in a proper, skilful and workmanlike-manner.

arguments.claim: Lessee breached Rule 27(1)(f) MCR 1960 by failing to conduct operations in a proper, skilful and workmanlike manner.

anchor.surface_text: Under Rule 27 1  f  the lessee is also required to companyduct operations in a proper, skilful and workmanlike-manner. It is abvious that there was a breach by the lessee of the companyenants and the Mineral Concession Rules when the firm stopped working the companyliery.

anchor.surface_text: It is companytended, however, that the wages were paid in full on the 17th of July but that obviously cannot do away with voluntary intermission which had already taken place for a few weeks. The firm in its representation to the Central Government said that it had plans to raise as much as 240,000 tons of companyl per year but their per

arguments.court_reasoning: firm did not fulfil obligations under lease; guilty of voluntary intermission and endangering colliery by neglect; poor performance evidence; entitled State to terminate under lease and rules

arguments.claim: The Central Government did not give a hearing to the firm and did not give reasons when performing quasi-judicial function of revision.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, argued before us that the Central Government did number give a hearing to the firm and also did number give any reasons in its order dismissing the application for revision. Reliance is placed upon two recent decisions of this Court which, following the earlier decision reported in Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala 1  have laid down that Government should give reasons when it performs quasi-judicial functions such as hearin- appeals and revisions.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: entral Government did number give a hearing to the firm and also did number give any reasons in its order dismissing the application for revision. Rel

arguments.court_reasoning: procedure under rules followed (obtained State comments, allowed firm reply); facts clear and spoke for themselves; distinguished precedents (different facts, no secret report, affirming order need not repeat reasons); detailed order not required as approving vindicated State action

arguments.claim: Procedure under Mineral Concession Rules for revision was correctly followed by Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: The Mineral Concession Rules make it incumbent on the Central Government to obtain the companyments of the State Government upon the application for revision and cast a duty on the Central Government to afford an opportunity to the applicant to make representations in respect of the companyments of the State Government. This procedure was companyrectly followed and the Central Government thus had a detailed discussion of the pros and companys of the case before it.

arguments.claim: State Government action was the only proper action and Central Government order sustainable as nothing withheld.

anchor.surface_text: The facts in the case were quite clear and spoke  1  1962 2 S.C.R. 339,  2  1966 1 S.C.R, 466. C.A.-No.635 of 1964 decided on September 23,1965. for themselves. The belated attempt to pay the back wages of the workmen did number undo the voluntary intermission for a significantly long period and did number wipe off the dereliction on the part of the firm by which the existence of the companyliery was gravely endangered.

arguments.claim: Firm's performance evidence shows lack of seriousness despite plans.

anchor.surface_text: The firm in its representation to the Central Government said that it had plans to raise as much as 240,000 tons of companyl per year but their performance shows that in April, 1962 they had raised less than 2,000 tons and numberhing in May, June and July.

holdings.text: there was a breach by the lessee of the covenants and the Mineral Concession Rules when the firm stopped working the colliery

anchor.surface_text: Under Rule 27 1 f the lessee is also required to conduct operations in a proper, skilful and workmanlike-manner. It is abvious that there was a breach by the lessee of the covenants and the Mineral Concession Rules when the firm stopped working the colliery.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Stoppage due to non-payment of wages despite obligation under Clause 3 Part VII and Rule 27(1)(f) to continue without voluntary intermission skilfully; admitted facts of quarrels and standstill

holdings.text: the firm did not fulfil its obligations under the lease and, whatever the reason, it was guilty of voluntary intermission in the working of the colliery and of endangering it by neglect. This entitled the State Government to step in and determine the lease under the terms of the lease and the provisions of the Mineral Concession Rules

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, there is no merit whatever in the submission of the firm that the action by the State Government was arbitrary and high-handed. It is plain that the firm did not fulfil its obligations under the lease and, whatever the reason, it was guilty of voluntary intermission in the working of the colliery and of endangering it by neglect. This entitled the State Government to step in and determine the lease under the terms of the lease and the provisions of the Mineral Concession Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Poor production, non-payment leading to flooding risk, no remedy despite notice; power under Rule 41 MCR 1949 and Rule 27(5) MCR 1960

holdings.text: there is no merit whatever in the submission of the firm that the action by the State Government was arbitrary and high-handed

anchor.surface_text: The firm in its representation to the Central Government said that it had plans to raise as much as 240,000 tons of coal per year but their performance shows that in April, 1962 they had raised less than 2,000 tons and nothing in May, June and July. In these circumstances, there is no merit whatever in the submission of the firm that the action by the State Government was arbitrary and high-handed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of dismal performance despite plans, voluntary intermission and neglect endangering colliery justified State intervention

holdings.text: This procedure was correctly followed and the Central Government thus had a detailed discussion of the pros and cons of the case before it

anchor.surface_text: The Mineral Concession Rules make it incumbent on the Central Government to obtain the comments of the State Government upon the application for revision and cast a duty on the Central Government to afford an opportunity to the applicant to make representations in respect of the comments of the State Government. This procedure was correctly followed and the Central Government thus had a detailed discussion of the pros and cons of the case before it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obtained State comments and allowed firm to reply as required under Rule 54 MCR 1960

holdings.text: the Central Government did not give a hearing to the firm and also did not give any reasons in its order dismissing the application for revision

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, argued before us that the Central Government did not give a hearing to the firm and also did not give any reasons in its order dismissing the application for revision. Reliance is placed upon two recent decisions of this Court which, following the earlier decision reported in Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala 1 have laid down that Government should give reasons when it performs quasi-judicial functions such as hearing appeals and revisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedure under rules followed; facts clear and self-evident; distinguished precedents (no secret reports, no disputed facts, affirming order need not repeat reasons); detailed order unnecessary as approving vindicated State action

holdings.text: The order of the Central Government is clearly sustainable on the material and it is not said that anything has been withheld from us

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, it is quite clear that the action of the State Government was not only right but proper and this is hardly a case in which any action other than rejecting the application for revision was called for and a detailed order was really not required because after all the Central Government was merely approving of the action taken in the case by the State Government, which stood completely vindicated. The order of the Central Government is clearly sustainable on the material and it is not said that anything has been withheld from us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Material on record supports rejection; full hearing via comments and replies; State action proper and only course

holdings.text: the wages were paid in full on the 17th of July but that obviously cannot do away with voluntary intermission which had already taken place for a few weeks

anchor.surface_text: It is contended, however, that the wages were paid in full on the 17th of July but that obviously cannot do away with voluntary intermission which had already taken place for a few weeks.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Belated payment post-60 day notice period does not remedy prior breach and intermission

anchor.surface_text: Under Rule 27 1 f the lessee is also required to conduct operations in a proper, skilful and workmanlike-manner. It is abvious that there was a breach by the lessee of the covenants and the Mineral Concession Rules when the firm stopped working the colliery.

In these circumstances, it is quite clear that the action of the State Government was number only right but proper and this is hardly a case in which any action other than rejecting the application for revision was called for and a detailed order was really number required because after all the Central Government was merely approving of the action taken in the case by the State Government, which stood companypletely vindicated.

In these circumstances, there is no merit whatever in the submission of the firm that the action by the State Government was arbitrary and high-handed. It is plain that the firm did not fulfil its obligations under the lease and, whatever the reason, it was guilty of voluntary intermission in the working of the colliery and of endangering it by neglect. This entitled the State Government to step in and determine the lease under the terms of the lease and the provisions of the Mineral Concession Rules.

In these circumstances, it is quite clear that the action of the State Government was number only right but proper and this is hardly a case in which any action other than rejecting the application for revision was called for and a detailed order was really number required because after all the Central Government was merely approving of the action taken in the case by the State Government, which stood companypletely vindicated.

edges.explanation: The holding explicitly rejects the submission that the action was arbitrary and high-handed, directly addressing the issue.

anchor.surface_text: The firm in its representation to the Central Government said that it had plans to raise as much as 240,000 tons of coal per year but their performance shows that in April, 1962 they had raised less than 2,000 tons and nothing in May, June and July. In these circumstances, there is no merit whatever in the submission of the firm that the action by the State Government was arbitrary and high-handed.

In these circumstances, it is quite clear that the action of the State Government was number only right but proper and this is hardly a case in which any action other than rejecting the application for revision was called for and a detailed order was really number required because after all the Central Government was merely approving of the action taken in the case by the State Government, which stood companypletely vindicated.

edges.explanation: h4 holds procedure correctly followed, addressing i4

anchor.surface_text: The Mineral Concession Rules make it incumbent on the Central Government to obtain the comments of the State Government upon the application for revision and cast a duty on the Central Government to afford an opportunity to the applicant to make representations in respect of the comments of the State Government. This procedure was correctly followed and the Central Government thus had a detailed discussion of the pros and cons of the case before it.

In these circumstances, it is quite clear that the action of the State Government was number only right but proper and this is hardly a case in which any action other than rejecting the application for revision was called for and a detailed order was really number required because after all the Central Government was merely approving of the action taken in the case by the State Government, which stood companypletely vindicated.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, argued before us that the Central Government did not give a hearing to the firm and also did not give any reasons in its order dismissing the application for revision. Reliance is placed upon two recent decisions of this Court which, following the earlier decision reported in Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala 1 have laid down that Government should give reasons when it performs quasi-judicial functions such as hearing appeals and revisions.

In these circumstances, it is quite clear that the action of the State Government was number only right but proper and this is hardly a case in which any action other than rejecting the application for revision was called for and a detailed order was really number required because after all the Central Government was merely approving of the action taken in the case by the State Government, which stood companypletely vindicated.

In these circumstances, it is quite clear that the action of the State Government was number only right but proper and this is hardly a case in which any action other than rejecting the application for revision was called for and a detailed order was really number required because after all the Central Government was merely approving of the action taken in the case by the State Government, which stood companypletely vindicated.

In these circumstances, it is quite clear that the action of the State Government was number only right but proper and this is hardly a case in which any action other than rejecting the application for revision was called for and a detailed order was really number required because after all the Central Government was merely approving of the action taken in the case by the State Government, which stood companypletely vindicated.
